texts.definition: Disposable game elements under the control of the game system or players that are either interacted with on a group level or have no individual distinguishing features from a set of other game elements.
markups: <style="Definition">Disposable game elements under the control of the game system or players that are either interacted with on a group level or have no individual distinguishing features from a set of other game elements.</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Units</style> is the term for game elements whose influence on gameplay is often considered from a group perspective, and whose uniqueness is not relevant for said gameplay. The <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> may have different actions and attributes associated with them but as players controls or interacts with many <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> simultaneously, the loss of single units is seldom the cause of losing a game.

All the pieces in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Stratego">Stratego</link></style> (except the king and the flag respectively) are <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> since there is no difference between members of the same category (e.g. Rooks, Bishops, and Pawns) and any may be lost without that causing the game to be immediately lost. In <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bloodbowl">Bloodbowl</link></style>, players control teams playing a version of American football in a fantasy setting and the team members (except star players) start indistinguishable from each other.

In the board game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Space%20Hulk">Space Hulk</link></style>, one of the players controls an essentially unlimited amount of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style>, called genestealers, which are replenished endlessly. The opposing player has a preset number of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style>, called space marines, which are not replenished once lost. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/X-COM%20series">X-COM series</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Jagged%20Alliance%20series">Jagged Alliance series</link></style> are examples of computer games putting players in charge of small groups. In contrast, roleplaying games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> have players controlling one character of their own but these are typically outnumbered in combat situations by inferior enemies controlled by game masters.

Computational power makes it possible to have large amounts of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> in a game, but typically do so by letting them be only partly under the players' direct control. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pik-Min">Pik-Min</link></style>, a more or less real-time puzzle game, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Lemmings">Lemmings</link></style> are examples of games that make heavy use of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> and the goo balls in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Goo">World of Goo</link></style> can to a lesser extent be seen as an example as well. Real-time strategy (RTS) games such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/StarCraft%20series">StarCraft series</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Age%20of%20Empires%20series">Age of Empires series</link></style> make heavy use of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style>, where the choice and use of the different available types of units is one of the strategic skills of the games. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Defense%20of%20the%20Ancients%20series">Defense of the Ancients series</link></style> is similar, but players have no control over the <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> (referred to as ''creeps''). Computer can of course also be used to expose players to many enemies - this is especially common in zombie games, e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead">Left 4 Dead</link></style> series, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dead%20Rising">Dead Rising</link></style> series, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Zombiepox">Zombiepox</link></style>.

A stereotypical <style="CurrentLink">Unit</style> in a game is a <style="Link"><link="diegetically-tangible-game-items">Diegetically Tangible Game Items</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="generic-adversaries">Generic Adversaries</link></style> that can perform <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> actions, some other type of action affecting other <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> or the environment (most often related to <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style>), and which others can <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style> through giving it <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style>. A basic requirement for <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> to exist is that the game system or the players have control over more than one game element, since having only one game element gives rise to the <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> patterns instead. The patterns are however compatible, as for example in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Defense%20of%20the%20Ancients">Defense of the Ancients</link></style> where each player in a <style="Link"><link="teams">Team</link></style> has a <style="Link"><link="characters">Character</link></style> but have no control over the many ''creeps'' that also fight on their side. <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> can be used also as <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> to the players' <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> (or <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>); in this case, they can be given various degrees of autonomy or be directly controlled through the <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>. For games using <style="Link"><link="line-sight">Line of Sight</link></style>, a basic decision regarding this is if <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> should block <style="Link"><link="line-sight">Line of Sight</link></style> or not.

Several design choices have to be made when using <style="CurrentLink">Units</style>. Maybe the most fundamental is if the units are supposed to be under players (including <style="Link"><link="ai-players">AI Players</link></style>) control or be under control of the game system. Their prime use when directed by the system is to be <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, and their behavior is in this case the result of being <style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agents</link></style> or having <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style>. The agency can also be used to make <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> take some <style="Link"><link="initiative">Initiative</link></style>, e.g. so that <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Warcraft">Warcraft</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/StarCraft">StarCraft</link></style> attack enemies found after having moved to a location specified by a player. The complexity and skills of these <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> can be designed to support both <style="Link"><link="casual-gameplay">Casual Gameplay</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style>, especially when used as <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> respectively. Quite often these types of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> have clearly different modes the operated in, for example going from a passive to active mode when an <style="Link"><link="alarms">Alarm</link></style> is triggered.

The amount of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> available to players is also one of the most fundamental choices. The number of the <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> may be preset so that the players have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resources</link></style> or it may be determined by <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style>, or depending on the player actions, during the set-up phase. When the players can affect the number of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> they may have during the gameplay through <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style>, these <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> are <style="Link"><link="renewable-resources">Renewable Resources</link></style> put into gameplay through <style="Link"><link="game-element-insertion">Game Element Insertion</link></style>. In other cases, the <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> may instead be <style="Link"><link="non-renewable-resources">Non-Renewable Resources</link></style>. New <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> can be rewards for completing sub goals, be produced from <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Resource%20Generators">Resource Generators</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="converters">Converters</link></style> that are under players' control, or be acquired through succeeding with <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style> goals of enemy <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> through <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Transfer%20of%20Control">Transfer of Control</link></style> actions. The <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> themselves may be part of neutral pools of <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style>, which players can take control over through succeeding with <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style> goals. In most cases, the lifetime of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> is governed by a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Producer-Consumer">Producer-Consumer</link></style> pattern. For example in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization series</link></style>, the production of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> is done in cities, and the <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> can be consumed in <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> through <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game%20Element%20Removal">Game Element Removal</link></style>. Using <style="Link"><link="converters">Converters</link></style>, or gaining control over new <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Producers">Producers</link></style>, may allow players to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Upgrading">Upgrade</link></style> <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> to give them <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style>. When <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style> as given to the <style="CurrentLink">Unit</style> classes, this give players as a whole <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style> while when done on individual <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> instead created localized <style="Link"><link="orthogonal-differentiation">Orthogonal Differentiation</link></style> but may turn <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> more into <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> than <style="CurrentLink">Units</style>. <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style> for <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> may arise from providing them with <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Abilities</link></style> but this may also be achieved simply by making several different types of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> available. <style="Link"><link="resource-caps">Resource Caps</link></style> can be used to limit the maximum number of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> available, and by this hindering one form of <style="Link"><link="positive-feedback-loops">Positive Feedback Loop</link></style> related to simply out producing opponents.

Beyond how many <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> are available to players is the decision of when the players can start to use them. Making all possible <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> available at the start makes them a <style="Link"><link="non-renewable-resources">Non-Renewable Resource</link></style> and typically speeds up the game if they can be eliminated during gameplay. Portioning the available <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> over time or giving them out as rewards for goals can be used to maintain <style="Link"><link="casual-gameplay">Casual Gameplay</link></style> and avoid <style="Link"><link="analysis-paralysis">Analysis Paralysis</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="alien-space-bats">Alien Space Bats</link></style> can be used to motivate the introduction both of individual <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> but also completely new types of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> during gameplay. In games with <style="Link"><link="resource-caps">Resource Caps</link></style> on the populations of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style>, increasing or decreasing the number of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> allowed can be used as <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style>. The number of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> can also be regulated by <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game%20Element%20Removal">Game Element Removal</link></style>, for example through being targets of the <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> from <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> motivated by other players' <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style> goals. Given that they can be present in large number, the destruction of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> or giving them <style="Link"><link="decreased-abilities">Decreased Abilities</link></style> does not need to be game breaking events.

The <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attributes">Attributes</link></style> (e.g. <style="Link"><link="health">Health</link></style>) of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> can either be identical - in order to stress the use of them as a group - or be <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asymmetric%20Abilities">Asymmetric</link></style> to encourage <style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style> related to <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style> (most efficiently promoted through <style="Link"><link="orthogonal-differentiation">Orthogonal Differentiation</link></style>). In the latter case, this can increase the value of each <style="CurrentLink">Unit</style> as it may not be replaced by another and may promote <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style> on when and where to use uncommon <style="CurrentLink">Units</style>. If the players can control the production of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style>, the existence of several different types can promote <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="trade-offs">Trade-Offs</link></style>, as the players have to decide what types of Units they want to acquire. Although the types of actions <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> may have can vary widely, unless <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> is possible for them they are likely to be interpreted more as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tokens">Tokens</link></style> than <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> (especially if their other actions do not have some directional component). An example of this can be found in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Small%20World">Small World</link></style> where <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> are placed through <style="Link"><link="tile-laying">Tile-Laying</link></style> rather than by being moved individually; this makes the <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> be somewhat more like <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tokens">Tokens</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="privileged-movement">Privileged Movement</link></style> can be used to modulate <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> further, e.g. to provide access to <style="Link"><link="safe-havens">Safe Havens</link></style>. However, <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> is a very common ability, even more so than for <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>, and make it possible to have <style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style> goals. When <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> are to be able to do more than one action per turn, <style="Link"><link="budgeted-action-points">Budgeted Action Points</link></style> are a common solution and varying how many action points <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> have is yet another was to give them <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asymmetric%20Abilities">Asymmetric Abilities</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="invulnerabilities">Invulnerabilities</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="vulnerabilities">Vulnerabilities</link></style> is two other options for making <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> have specific differences, most often related to <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> but sometimes also to <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style>. Although uncommon, combining the two make it possible to give <style="Link"><link="achilles-heels">Achilles' Heels</link></style> to <style="CurrentLink">Units</style>.

<style="Link"><link="diegetically-tangible-game-items">Diegetically Tangible Game Items</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style> can both be used to influence the possible <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style>. The <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> themselves can also be <style="Link"><link="diegetically-tangible-game-items">Diegetically Tangible Game Items</link></style> and are then <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style> to each other, and in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Wargames">Wargames</link></style> it is common to modify them by giving them <style="Link"><link="zone-control">Zone of Control</link></style> abilities (this is also done in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization series</link></style>). <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style> can also affect <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> but just as well provide <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>. The game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Lemmings">Lemmings</link></style> is a good example of how the <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> can be modulated: using both <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style>, and having the ''Lemmings'' as <style="Link"><link="diegetically-tangible-game-items">Diegetically Tangible Game Items</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="laning">Laning</link></style> is another way of modifying the <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style>, here by creating multiple different lanes which the <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> use to move towards a goal area.

The value of units relative to each other is also worth considering. This may typically affect the cost to create them with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Producers">Producers</link></style> and be linked to their power, especially if the <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> have different <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Set%20of%20Actions">Limited Set of Actions</link></style> available or if any <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> exist. For game designs that make use of <style="Link"><link="line-sight">Line of Sight</link></style>, this is a possible area of providing varying levels of abilities. The different abilities of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> do not have to be inherent; the use of <style="Link"><link="controllers">Controllers</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style> can explain various <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> as can <style="Link"><link="location-fixed-abilities">Location-Fixed Abilities</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="alarms">Alarms</link></style>, while <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style> can explain <style="Link"><link="privileged-movement">Privileged Movement</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="orthogonal-differentiation">Orthogonal Differentiation</link></style> between <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> may be used to set up <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Paper-Rock-Scissors">Paper-Rock-Scissors</link></style> power relations so that some weak unique can be powerful in special cases. This is for example done in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Stratego">Stratego</link></style>, where the weakest <style="CurrentLink">Unit</style>, the spy, is the only type to be able to kill the most powerful one, the Marshal. This evens the usefulness of the <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> even though they have varying power, and typically also provides more <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style>.

Looking at a larger perspective, the availability of different types of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> can actively create different gameplay phases and indicate shifts from one to another. For example, <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style> may be only allowed to those with <style="Link"><link="privileged-movement">Privileged Movement</link></style> while those that can construct <style="Link"><link="bases">Bases</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="installations">Installations</link></style> may be needed for <style="Link"><link="expansion">Expansion</link></style>. Continuing, <style="Link"><link="exploitation">Exploitation</link></style> can be encouraged through <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> good at collecting <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> and availability of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> with the best <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> abilities suggest a shift to <style="Link"><link="extermination">Extermination</link></style> phases.

Providing players with sufficient information about the current state of the <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> can require either <style="Link"><link="geospatial-game-widgets">Geospatial Game Widgets</link></style> to provide information, e.g. their <style="Link"><link="health">Health</link></style>, co-located with the <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> or the use of <style="Link"><link="game-state-overviews">Game State Overviews</link></style> (or a <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style> that can be viewed in its entirety all at once). Many games using <style="CurrentLink">Units</style>, and especially those where the number of the <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> can change over time, make use of a <style="Link"><link="cameras">Camera</link></style> for <style="Link"><link="third-person-views">Third-Person Views</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="god-fingers">God Fingers</link></style> to allow players to navigate <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> in order to locate and select which <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> to use.

<style="CurrentLink">Units</style> typically have no <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> associated with them since they are most often meant to be indistinguishable from each other. However, the patterns can be combined when most of the player interaction with the <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> are on the group level but some individual management occurs intermittently. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/X-COM%20series">X-COM series</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Jagged%20Alliance">Jagged Alliance</link></style> series are examples of this. It is however more common that <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> are affected by <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-constructs">Abstract Player Constructs</link></style>, either on a individual level to handle a limited range of information (e.g. health, experience, and promotions in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization series</link></style>) or as modifications due to a country's or civilization's technology level (e.g. modifications of <style="CurrentLink">Unit</style> attrition in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Victoria%20series">Victoria series</link></style>). Allowing the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Naming">Naming</link></style> of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style>, e.g. ships in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Europa%20Universalis%20series">Europa Universalis series</link></style>, can be seen as a minimal change to <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-constructs">Abstract Player Constructs</link></style> but can also be used to help ease <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Micro%20Management">Micro Management</link></style>.

Many of the aspects of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style>, including the numbers available and which abilities they should possess, can be put partly in a player's control by using <style="Link"><link="heterogeneous-game-element-ownership">Heterogeneous Game Element Ownership</link></style> so they themselves choose which <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> they should have.

<style="CurrentLink">Units</style> that have different abilities are typically distinguished from each other through use of <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style> - this to help players understand the game state and more easily navigate to specific units.

<style="CurrentLink">Units</style> are common solutions to the problem of having the <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> of many individuals or groups that together work towards a goal - but this <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> also restricts their appearance and behavior. <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> which are under another player's or the game system's control are typically examples of <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style>. If compared with single <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> with the same action repertoire, <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> allow a greater <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> simply because a choice can be made for each <style="CurrentLink">Unit</style>. In addition, having several game elements that can be controlled can allow <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="collaborative-actions">Collaborative Actions</link></style> which would be impossible otherwise, but this may require <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attention%20Swapping">Attention Swapping</link></style>. They typically also function as a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resource</link></style> that can be used to achieve gameplay goals; <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> cannot be used in this way although their <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="health">Health</link></style> can. As a potential downside to these effects, having many <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> often requires more input to the system which can in effect become <style="Link"><link="excise">Excise</link></style>. This is especially true in <style="Link"><link="self-facilitated-games">Self-Facilitated Games</link></style>. In <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> that are also <style="Link"><link="turn-based-games">Turn-Based Games</link></style> they may cause <style="Link"><link="analysis-paralysis">Analysis Paralysis</link></style>, partly because they add complexity and possibility for <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style> but also since they provide a form of internal <style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style> if the movement and actions of each <style="CurrentLink">Unit</style> is considered a turn.

<style="CurrentLink">Units</style> are <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> in games, and one example of this is that each of them can be a point to disperse <style="Link"><link="fog-war">Fog of War</link></style>. For this reason, acquiring or constructing them represents a form of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Investment">Investment</link></style> in a <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-constructs">Abstract Player Constructs</link></style> that lead to <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-construct-development">Abstract Player Construct Development</link></style>.

For this reason, players controlling <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> that are in some form of danger to receive <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> related to these have the <style="Link"><link="continuous-goals">Continuous Goals</link></style> of trying to <style="Link"><link="survive">Survive</link></style>, especially when the <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> for losing <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> include <style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style> and the ability to perform <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style>. When the <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> can be avoided by <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> this results in players having <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style> goals. <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> with <style="Link"><link="achilles-heels">Achilles' Heels</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="vulnerabilities">Vulnerabilities</link></style> can add extra motivation for players to engage in <style="Link"><link="conceal">Conceal</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style> goals.

This of course happens in games with <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> but since gameplay may continue when <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> are lost, or the consequences are not so severe, players may need to live with those effects rather than restarting the game or entering <style="Link"><link="save-load-cycles">Save-Load Cycles</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> are not only affected by the possibility of  <style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style> in games; they modulate <style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style> since they may make the <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> into <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resources</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Units</style> allow the players to have multiple <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style> where they can affect <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> without breaking their <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style>. However, they may create <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style> due to demands of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attention%20Swapping">Attention Swapping</link></style>. This is especially likely if the game does not have <style="Link"><link="game-state-overviews">Game State Overviews</link></style> which shows relevant information about each player's <style="CurrentLink">Units</style>, or if the game does not provide enough information through <style="Link"><link="geospatial-game-widgets">Geospatial Game Widgets</link></style> about the <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> so that players need to select them to get the information.

Various <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> can have different <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Set%20of%20Actions">Limited Set of Actions</link></style> by making use of <style="Link"><link="orthogonal-differentiation">Orthogonal Differentiation</link></style>, so using them can require the players to make <style="Link"><link="trade-offs">Trade-Offs</link></style> between different types of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style>. Different stages of the gameplay can further require different types of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style>, allowing <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style> as do games using <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Paper-Rock-Scissors">Paper-Rock-Scissors</link></style> power structures between the different types of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style>. Creating a good set of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> that work well together can be seen as <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style> besides the activity of constructing individual <style="CurrentLink">Units</style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Units</style> let the players simulate <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> even in <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style> as they can let <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style> appear to be <style="Link"><link="team-combos">Team Combos</link></style>. This encourages <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style> and allows players to do <style="Link"><link="resource-management">Resource Management</link></style> on a higher level than using <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>, as the destruction or death of <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> may in some cases even be advantageous and necessary. Thus <style="CurrentLink">Units</style> can be seen as a use of <style="Link"><link="parallel-lives">Parallel Lives</link></style> which in contrast to <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> are more or less dispensable.

<style="CurrentLink">Units</style> have compatibility problems with the <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style> pattern since the former assumes both diegetic individuality and not being under player control.

<style="CurrentLink">Units</style> are problematic to combine with <style="Link"><link="detective-structures">Detective Structures</link></style> since the be necessity provide players with several different viewpoints to <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>.
